turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Simon, I'm going to check ROK's secondary readout unit.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Roger.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Simon, what's happening?!

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: He tried to disconnect ROK.  It gassed him.  That computer is running this ship and we're heading right for the sun.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Can't we change course?

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: We're computer locked and the manual navigation unit is down.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: My career is shot.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Your career!  What about the lives of those people out there.  Simon, what happened to the man I thought I loved?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Simon, I didn't want it to end like this. We can be friends!  You'll die out there.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Simon, what are you saying?!

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Elaine, ask ROK for a field interference scan.  Those sun spots might give us a problem with our communications.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I don't think we have any alternative, Captain.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: I see.  What do you think our alternatives are?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: We have to disconnect ROK's higher brain functions without disturbing his regulatory system.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Roger.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You can do it from up here, Captain.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: I'd rather sit down for this one, Elaine.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: No, I mean you can do it from the cockpit.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Roger.  You better get back there and monitor the regulatory unit.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Intermitant failure in scan mode "R". Analyze.

turns.speaker: ROK
turns.text: Negative.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: That doesn't make sense.  Repeat analysis.

turns.speaker: ROK
turns.text: Negative.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: That's not possible.

turns.speaker: ROK
turns.text: Cut the Doubting Thomas shit, Elaine.  I know where I'm coming from on this.

turns.speaker: ROK
turns.text: Elaine, I'm sorry about that little outburst a moment ago.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: That's okay, ROK.

turns.speaker: ROK
turns.text: Can I say something of a personal nature to you?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: ROK
turns.text: You have great tits.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Request; comprehensive electrical systems check.

turns.speaker: ROK
turns.text: Systems check positive.  Look, Elaine, I...

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Request; life support systems check.

turns.speaker: ROK
turns.text: Life support check.  Elaine, it's obvious you've been ignoring me.  You're a woman. I can relate to that.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Request; self-analysis of ROK hardware and software systems regarding behavioral changes.

turns.speaker: ROK
turns.text: There's nothing wrong with me, Elaine. What about tonight -- just you and me.  We can be alone.  I can get rid of everyone else on the ship -- I've already proven <u>that</u>.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Will Scraps be able to sit with us, Dad?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: We'll have to check, Jimmy.  It's a pretty long trip to Mercury.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I sure an glad they let Scraps ride up here with us.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I bet Scraps is going to love Mercury.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Do you think things will be a lot different on Mercury, Dad?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's going to be terrific.  A whole new world, new kids to play with.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: How many kids get a chance to live on another planet.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: No more kids yelling, 'Your old man's a thieving rapist'?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Look, a man can make an honest mistake!! Anyway, she was asking for it!  They're all asking for it all the time!!

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Come on up, Jimmy.  Say, that's some puppy.  What's his name?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Scraps.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Can I hold him?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: He's a boy dog.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Do you like it when Scraps sleeps on his back, Jimmy?

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Take this, Joey.  It's my last few bucks. You'll need a hot meal when you get there.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We've spent everything on these operations.  Is it really worth it?  We've pawned your mother's wedding ring.  The kids have no winter clothes...

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Joey, what's more important, the kids' clothes or your sexual potency.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I don't want to hear that word!

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: Okay, Joey.  The Doc says you gotta relax. This hospital in Des Moines is the best sex clinic in the country.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: All right.  Here.

turns.speaker: WIFE
turns.text: What...?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Joe, you don't want to blow that thing and kill all these innocent people.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I don't want to live anymore.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Joe, the insurance policy won't help your wife and kids.  You bought auto insurance, not life insurance.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's right, Joe.  Now, no one's going to hurt you and no one has to know what's wrong with you.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You're sure?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm sure.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: A couple eggs and juice would be nice, Mary.  Over.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: How would you like your eggs, Captain? Over.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: No.  Poached.  Over.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Poached <u>and</u> over, Captain Oveur?  Over.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Just poached on toast.  Over.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: That's how I want them.  Poached.  Over.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: All right, Captain Oveur.  Over.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Poached!  Not over!  Over!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Captain, the coffee machine is jammed and I don't like it.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Have you tried it with a little cinnamon?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Which passenger is Joe Salucci?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sixteen 'C', why?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: He's carrying a bomb.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: A b...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, a bomb.  Now, as discreetly as possible, I want you to move the passengers into the lounge.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What should I say?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Anything.  Just don't let Salucci think we're onto him.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Captain Oveur?

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Mr. Kurtz, I presume.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: We don't have much time.  Let's move. I'll explain everything.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: That's how dry cleaning works.  Now I'd like to quickly go over the digestive system of amphibians.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Do you think it's necessary to explain <u>everything</u>?

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Good to be aboard, gentlemen.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Captain Oveur, your navigator, Mr. Unger, and your first officer, Mr. Dunn.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Whenever your're ready, Captain.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Yes, sir, commander.  This is Mercury One.  Everything seems A- okay up here and ready for count-down.

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: You folks need any help?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Thanks, but we have a terrific woman in on Thursdays.

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: Say, isn't that Dr. Barrington, the world- renowned agronomist?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: It's a privilege to meet you, sir, I'm familiar with all your work.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Let's go, Daddy.  We have to check in.  He was never appreciated at the Institute.

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: Ah, yes, the Institute, I'm familiar with it.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Now he's D-Y-I-N-Ging and wants to be buried on Mercury.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I have to see Bud Kruger.

turns.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
turns.text: Do you have an appointment, sir?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, dammit.  It's a matter of life or death.

turns.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
turns.text: You'll have to be more specific than that, sir.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: All right, it's a matter of death.

turns.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
turns.text: Death, death.  How about the first Thursday in March, ten o'clock.

turns.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
turns.text: You can't go in there!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Don't try to stop me!

turns.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
turns.text: But that's not a door.  The door's over there.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Are you on the Mercury mission?

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: That's right, Striker.  And we're getting married when we return.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: You're seeing bugs where they don't exist, Striker.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Look at this wiring.  It's shorting out under high temperatures.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: You're tired, Striker, overworked.  That wiring meets all the safety specifications.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I know you've been subtly spreading the word that I'm having a breakdown.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Striker.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Kurtz, you're drunk.  Who's in command of this ship?

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: That damn computer has taken over.  I'm getting out.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Then Elaine was right.

turns.speaker: SIMON
turns.text: Don't talk to me about Elaine.  Outta my way!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Pull yourself together!  We've got to...

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Excuse me, are you alright?  I noticed you talking to yourself.  I'm a nurse.  Can I be of some help?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh... oh, thank you.  It's nothing.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: You don't have to thank me, I'm a nurse. This is my father, Dr. Barrington.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Not Dr. Barrington, the world renowned agronomist?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Yes.  He's dying <u>a-n-d</u> wants to be buried on Mercury.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm familiar with your work, Doctor. You'll have to excuse me, I have to go.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: You don't have to excuse yourself.  I'm a nurse.  I understand.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: You've been hurt.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm getting over it.  If a relationship isn't working, you can't force it.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: No, I mean your head.  Sit down.  I'll take a look at it.  I'm a nurse.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Do you want to talk about it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I opened this panel and a vacuum cleaner hit me.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: No.  I mean your relationship.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: We were in love but I'm not sure I know what love is anymore.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Love's the same as it always was.  It's people who change.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: People change in relation to each other. Love changes on its own.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Not if the people change together in relation to that love.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Sure.  But that's only when the love itself goes unchanged.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Then the relationship remains the same and the love changes only when there's change in the two people who share that love.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I just wish it was that simple.  We really were in love.  You know how it is when you laugh all the time.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: No.  It's hard to L-A-U-G-H when your father's dying.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well, we laughed.  We laughed all the time.

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: I happened to be passing, and I thought you might like some corfee.

turns.speaker: BERNICE
turns.text: That's very nice of you. Thank you.

turns.speaker: BERNICE
turns.text: Ah, won't you sit down?

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: Thank you. Cream?

turns.speaker: BERNICE
turns.text: No, thank you. I take it black. Like my men.

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: Were you vacationing in Los Angeles?

turns.speaker: BERNICE
turns.text: Well, it really wasn't a vacation. You see, I'm a teacher in the New York City school system, and I was attending a seminar on visual aids to education. Are you from L.A.?

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: No. I'm from Washington, D.C. I'm a lobbyist for the Small Businessmen's Assocation.

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: After my wife died, I felt like a fifth wheel. You know, so many years being with one person -- a very wonderful person -- makes you always think of yourself as part of a pair...When Ethel passed away, I was lost. I couldn't function socially and I couldn't function in business.

turns.speaker: BERNICE
turns.text: Well, after a thing like that you wouldn't be expected to.

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: But I think it's time we stopped talking about me. A woman like you -- why haven't you ever married?

turns.speaker: BERNICE
turns.text: Well, I'm afraid that's a question that's all too easy to answer.

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: I know the answer -- Career. A smart woman like you became so involved in your work, you didn't have time for marriage.

turns.speaker: BERNICE
turns.text: I wish I could fool myself into believing that that's the reason. The truth of the matter is, nobody ever asked me.

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: You know, here we are having coffee together, and discussing education and business and economy...and we don't even know each other's names...full names I mean.

turns.speaker: BERNICE
turns.text: Mine's Eleanor. Eleanor Schiff.

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: That's a lovely name. Mine's Milton...Milt Ettenhenim. But my friends call me 'Bubbles.'

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: I'm sure we'll both make it...but just in case one of us...well, is there a message you'd like me to give someone?

turns.speaker: BERNICE
turns.text: No. I'm all alone.

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: Just in case I don't have a chance to say goodbye, I want you to know that I haven't spent so many pleasant hours for many years.

turns.speaker: BERNICE
turns.text: That's a very nice compliment, and I'd like to say that...you've done the same for me.

turns.speaker: CAREY
turns.text: Hello, I'm Paul Carey from the airline. I'm here to pick up Captain Kramer.

turns.speaker: MRS. KRAMER
turns.text: Oh, yes. Come in, Paul. Rex will be right out.

turns.speaker: MRS. KRAMER
turns.text: Shep, sit...sit! So, I understand you've got a real emergency down there.

turns.speaker: CAREY
turns.text: Well, to tell the truth, they really didn't fill me in on many of the details. Just told me to pick up Captain Kramer.

turns.speaker: MRS. KRAMER
turns.text: Something about a plane with no pilot?

turns.speaker: CAREY
turns.text: Yeah, something like that, but as I say, they didn't have time to tell me very much.

turns.speaker: MRS. KRAMER
turns.text: Shep, no! I'll bet you have exciting things happen all the time down there.

turns.speaker: CAREY
turns.text: ...but after...awhile...you begin to...  ...get used to it.

turns.speaker: MRS. KRAMER
turns.text: Shep, no! He gets so excited when new people are here.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Both pilots!

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: Can you fly this airplane and land it?

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Surely you can't be serious.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: I <u>am</u> serious, and don't call me Shirley! What flying experience have you had?

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Well, I flew single-engine fighters in the Air Force, but this plane has four engines. It's an entirely different kind of flying...<u>all</u> <u>together</u>!!!

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: Elaine, I haven't time to put this gently, so I'll be very direct. Everyone of us on this plane is in a desperate situation. Mister Striker is the only hope we've got.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Let's see. Those are the flaps, that's the thrust, this must turn on the landing lights.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: ...safe and sound and free to pursue a life of religious fulfillment.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Chicago, the passengers are beginning to panic. When do we start down?

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: Will the hospital equipment be at the airport?

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Yes, everything they've got. How are the passengers doing?

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: I won't deceive you, Mister Striker. We're running out of time.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Surely there must be something you can do.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: I'm doing everything I can! -- And stop calling me Shirley!

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: George Zipp said that?

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: And the last thing he said to me, "Doc," he said, "Sometime when the crew is up against it and the breaks are beating the boys, tell them to go out there with all they've got and win just one for the Zipper. I don't know where I'll be then, Doc," he said, "but I won't smell too good. That's for sure."

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Excuse me, Doc, I've got a plane to land.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: Captain, how soon can we land?

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: I can't tell.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: Can't you take a guess?

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Well...not for another two hours.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: You can't take a guess for another two hours?

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: No, I mean we can't <u>land</u> for another two hours. Fog has closed down everything this side of the mountains. We've got to go through to Chicago!

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: What is it, Doctor? What's happening?

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: I'm not sure. I haven't seen anything like this since the Lina Wertmuller Film Festival.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Sir. Excuse me, sir. I'm sorry to have to wake you. Are you a doctor?

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: We have some passengers who are very sick. Could you come and take a look at them?

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: Yes. Yes, of course.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: You'd better tell the Captain. We've got to land as soon as we can. This woman has to be gotten to a hospital.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: A hospital? What is it?

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: It's a big building with patients. But that's not important right now. Tell the Captain I must speak to him.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Certainly.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: What was it we had for dinner tonight?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Well, we had a choice. Steak or fish.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: Yes, yes, I remember. I had lasagna.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: What did he have?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: He had fish.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Doctor Rumack, Mister Hammen ate fish. And Randy says there are five more cases, and they ate fish, too.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: Let's see now. The co-pilot had fish. What did the navigator eat?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: He had fish, too.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Just how serious is it, doctor?

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: Extremely serious. It starts with a slight fever.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: Elaine, you're a member of this crew. Can you face some unpleasant facts?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: All right. Unless I can get all these people to a hospital quickly, I can't even be sure of saving their lives. Now, is there anyone else on board who can land this plane?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: No. No one that I know of.

turns.speaker: DR. RUMACK
turns.text: I think you ought to know what our chances are. The life of everyone on board depends on just one thing: finding someone back there who not only can fly this plane, but who didn't have fish for dinner.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Elaine!

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Ted!

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: I came home early and found your note. I guess you meant for me to read it later. Elaine, I've got to talk to you.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I just don't want to go over it any more.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: I know things haven't been right for a long time, but it'll be different. If you'll just be patient, I can work things out.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I have been patient and I've tried to help, but you wouldn't even let me do that.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Don't you feel anything for me at all any more?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: It takes so many things to make love last. Most of all it takes respect. And I can't live with a man I don't respect!

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Look, you'll be back in town tomorrow night. We'll have dinner -- talk it over.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I won't be back. I've requested the Atlanta run.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Elaine, not yet. I promise you I really can change.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Then why don't you take the job that Louie Netz offered you at Boeing?

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: You know I haven't been able to get near an airplane since the war. And even if I could, they wouldn't hire me because of my war record.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Your <u>war</u> <u>record</u>? You're the only one keeping that alive. For everyone else it's ancient history.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: You expect me to believe that?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: It's the truth. What's hurt you the most is your record since the war. Different cities, different jobs, and not one of them shows you can accept any real responsibility.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: But if you'll just give me...

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: It's too late, Ted. When I get back to Chicago, I'm going to start my life all over again. I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Ted, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Elaine, I've got to talk to you.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You...you shouldn't have come. I don't have time now.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: My orders came through. My squadron ships out tomorrow. I'll be leading a very important mission.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Oh, Ted, please be careful. I worry about you so much.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: I love you, Elaine.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I love you.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Elaine, just hear me out. I know things haven't been right for a long time. But it will be different...like it was in the beginning. Remember?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I remember everything. All I have are memories.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Mostly I remember...the nights when we were together. I remember how you used to hold me...and how I used to sit on your face and wriggle...and then afterwards how we'd watch until the sun came up. When it did, it was almost like...like each new day was created...only for us.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: That's the way I've always wanted it to be, Elaine.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: But it won't be. Not as long as you insist on living in the past!

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You got a telegram from head­quarters today.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Headquarters!? What is it?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: It's a big building where the generals meet. But that's not important right now. They've cleared you of any blame for what happened on that raid. Isn't that good news?

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Is it? Because of my mistake six men didn't return from that raid.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Seven. Lieutenant Zipp died this morning. Ted, Doctor Sandler says you'll be out in a week. Isn't that wonderful?

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: I wish I could say the same for George Zipp.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Be patient, Ted. No one expects you to get over this immediately.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What's his problem?

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: That's Lieutennt Hurwitz. Severe shell shock. He thinks he's Ethel Merman.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: I think they're getting the hang of it! When we re-enlist I'll teach them baseball!

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Ted, I don't want to stay here. It's time for us to go back home -- to the plans we made before the war.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: A lot of people made plans before the war. Like George Zipp.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Ted! What are you doing? You can't fly this plane!

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: That's what I've been trying to tell these people.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Rain.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: And a little ice.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: And a little ice!

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Sluggish. Like a wet sponge.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Sluggish. Like a wet sponge.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: It's a damn good thing he doesn't know how much I hate his guts.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: It's a damn good thing you don't know how much he hates your guts.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Rats! I've lost number three.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What happened, Ted? What went wrong?

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Oil pressure. I forgot to check the oil pressure. When Kramer hears about this, the shit's gonna hit the fan.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: But Ted, you're the only...

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: I don't care. I just don't have what it takes. They'd be better off with someone who'd never flown before.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Ted...

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I wanted you to know -- now -- I'm very proud.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: Tell them the gear is down and we're ready to land.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: The gear is down.

turns.speaker: STRIKER
turns.text: See them, Elaine?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: We have a visitor.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: We'd better get back now.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Joey can stay up here for a while if he'd like to.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Hey, we've been waiting for you. A little bit late tonight.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Who wants to be first?

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Airsick?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I think so, but I've never seen it so acute.

turns.speaker: OVEUR
turns.text: Find out if there's a doctor on board, as quietly as you can.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Oh, Bill, I'm going to miss you so much.

turns.speaker: SOLDIER
turns.text: You promise you'll write.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Every day.

turns.speaker: SOLDIER
turns.text: Good-bye, darling.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Oh, Bill, I'll keep it. I'll keep it with me all the time.

turns.speaker: SOLDIER
turns.text: So long, darling. Good-bye. Take care of yourself.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Bill! Bill! Good-bye, Bill.

turns.speaker: SOLDIER
turns.text: Good-bye, darling.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Good-bye, darling. I love you. I love you, darling.

turns.speaker: SOLDIER
turns.text: Good-bye, darling.

turns.speaker: KRAMER
turns.text: And get that finger out of your ear. You don't know where that finger's been! Gunderson?

turns.speaker: GUNDERSON
turns.text: Yes, Captain?

turns.speaker: KRAMER
turns.text: Did you decide on a runway yet?

turns.speaker: GUNDERSON
turns.text: Runway niner. It's the longest, and directly into the wind.

turns.speaker: GUNDERSON
turns.text: Eight miles. Turn right to heading zero eight niner.

turns.speaker: KRAMER
turns.text: You are now eight miles from the airport. Turn right to a heading of zero eight niner, throttle back slightly and begin to lose altitude to fifteen hundred feet.

turns.speaker: GUNDERSON
turns.text: He's all over the place! Nine hundred feet up to thirteen hundred feet! What an asshole!

turns.speaker: KRAMER
turns.text: Watch your altitude, Striker. It's too erratic. You can't come straight in. You've got enough fuel left for two hours flying. You've got to stay up there 'til we get a break in the weather.

turns.speaker: GUNDERSON
turns.text: He's right on the heading.

turns.speaker: KRAMER
turns.text: All right, he's on final now! Put out all runway lights except niner.

turns.speaker: SHIRLEY
turns.text: Jack, isn't that Fred Bliffert over there in the blue turtleneck? Maybe he's on our flight to Chicago.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah, I think he is.  Hey, Fred!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What did you think of 'Great Expectations?'

turns.speaker: SHIRLEY
turns.text: Well, it wasn't all that I had hoped.

turns.speaker: SHIRLEY
turns.text: Oh, I can't stand it.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: How ya doing, honey?

turns.speaker: SHIRLEY
turns.text: Oh Jack, I'm so warm. I'm burning up.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Here.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Wait a minute. I know you. You're Kareem Abdul Jabbar. You play basketball for the Los Angeles Lakers!

turns.speaker: MURDOCK
turns.text: I'm sorry, son, but you must have me confused with someone else. My name is Roger Murdock. I'm the co-pilot.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: You <u>are</u> Kareem. I've seen you play. My Dad's got season tickets!

turns.speaker: MURDOCK
turns.text: I think you should go back to your seat now, Joey. Right, Clarence?

turns.speaker: MURDOCK
turns.text: I'm an airline pilot.  Ah, Clarence, according to my calculations, with this tailwind we ought to be able to make up an additional fifteen minutes over the Rockies.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I think you're the greatest. But my Dad says you don't work hard enough on defense.

turns.speaker: MURDOCK
turns.text: Denver Control, this is Flight two-zero- niner intersecting Victor Airway seven- niner-niner.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: ...and that lots of times you don't even run down court.

turns.speaker: MURDOCK
turns.text: We are turning left to a heading of zero- niner-niner.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: ...and that you don't really try, except during the playoffs.

turns.speaker: MURDOCK
turns.text: The hell I don't! I'm out there busting my buns every night.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Hi!

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: I'm Randy.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I'm Lisa. Oh, you have a guitar!

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: I thought maybe you'd like to hear a song.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Oh, I'd love to.

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: Okay, this is one of my favorites.

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: Would either of you like another cup of coffee?

turns.speaker: MRS. HAMMEN
turns.text: I will, but Jim won't.

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MRS. HAMMEN
turns.text: Oh, Stewardess. My husband is very sick. Can you do something, please?

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: Well, the doctor will be with you in just a moment. One thing: do you know what he had for dinner?

turns.speaker: MRS. HAMMEN
turns.text: Yes, of course. We both had fish. Why?

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: Oh, it's nothing to be alarmed about. We'll get back to you very quickly.
